articles.headline: Russian Economy Contracts Sharply as War and Sanctions Take Hold
articles.snippet: The country’s gross domestic product from April through June declined 4 percent from a year earlier, new government data shows.
articles.abstract: The country’s gross domestic product from April through June declined 4 percent from a year earlier, new government data shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Russian economy contracted steeply in the second quarter as the country felt the brunt of the economic consequences of its war in Ukraine, in what experts believe to be the start of a yearslong downturn.
articles.byline: By Eshe Nelson and Patricia Cohen

articles.headline: A Victory for Biden, and a Bet on America’s Future
articles.snippet: Congress gave final approval to the Inflation Reduction Act, which will lower the cost of prescription drugs, extend health care subsidies and invest billions into climate and energy programs.
articles.abstract: Congress gave final approval to the Inflation Reduction Act, which will lower the cost of prescription drugs, extend health care subsidies and invest billions into climate and energy programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He promised a new social safety net. He pledged to develop a robust plan to fight global warming. He vowed to reduce the gap between rich and poor by making the wealthy “pay their fair share.”
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: As Right-Wing Rhetoric Escalates, So Do Threats and Violence
articles.snippet: Both threats of political violence and actual attacks have become a steady reality of American life. Experts blame dehumanizing and apocalyptic language.
articles.abstract: Both threats of political violence and actual attacks have become a steady reality of American life. Experts blame dehumanizing and apocalyptic language.
articles.lead_paragraph: The armed attack this week on an F.B.I. office in Ohio by a supporter of former President Donald J. Trump who was enraged by the bureau’s search of Mr. Trump’s private residence in Florida was one of the most disturbing episodes of right-wing political violence in recent months.

articles.headline: Defamation Suit About Election Falsehoods Puts Fox on Its Heels
articles.snippet: The suit, filed by Dominion Voting Systems, could be one of the most consequential First Amendment cases in a generation.
articles.abstract: The suit, filed by Dominion Voting Systems, could be one of the most consequential First Amendment cases in a generation.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the weeks after President Donald J. Trump lost the 2020 election, the Fox Business host Lou Dobbs claimed to have “tremendous evidence” that voter fraud was to blame. That evidence never emerged but a new culprit in a supposed scheme to rig the election did: Dominion Voting Systems, a maker of election technology whose algorithms, Mr. Dobbs said, “were designed to be inaccurate.”

articles.headline: Asian American Voters Rallied for Democrats in 2020. Will They Again?
articles.snippet: The party confronts a mood of frustration among the rising electoral force that helped vault it to power. The campaign in Georgia will test that bond.
articles.abstract: The party confronts a mood of frustration among the rising electoral force that helped vault it to power. The campaign in Georgia will test that bond.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — At a brightly lit restaurant in suburban Atlanta, nestled in a tidy neighborhood of office buildings and private drives, State Senator Michelle Au brought up the mass shooting that lingers as a singular trauma in the local Asian American community.

articles.headline: Trump Lawyer Told Justice Dept. That Classified Material Had Been Returned
articles.snippet: The lawyer signed a statement in June that all documents marked as classified and held in boxes in storage at Mar-a-Lago had been given back. The search at the former president’s home on Monday turned up more.
articles.abstract: The lawyer signed a statement in June that all documents marked as classified and held in boxes in storage at Mar-a-Lago had been given back. The search at the former president’s home on Monday turned up more.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least one lawyer for former President Donald J. Trump signed a written statement in June asserting that all material marked as classified and held in boxes in a storage area at Mr. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago residence and club had been returned to the government, four people with knowledge of the document said.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: On TikTok, Election Misinformation Thrives Ahead of Midterms
articles.snippet: The fast-growing platform’s poor track record during recent voting abroad does not bode well for elections in the U.S., researchers said.
articles.abstract: The fast-growing platform’s poor track record during recent voting abroad does not bode well for elections in the U.S., researchers said.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Germany, TikTok accounts impersonated prominent political figures during the country’s last national election. In Colombia, misleading TikTok posts falsely attributed a quotation from one candidate to a cartoon villain and allowed a woman to masquerade as another candidate’s daughter. In the Philippines, TikTok videos amplified sugarcoated myths about the country’s former dictator and helped his son prevail in the country’s presidential race.

articles.headline: How Frustration Over TikTok Has Mounted in Washington
articles.snippet: National security concerns over the Chinese-owned viral video app remain unresolved. Lawmakers and regulators are increasingly pushing for action.
articles.abstract: National security concerns over the Chinese-owned viral video app remain unresolved. Lawmakers and regulators are increasingly pushing for action.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early last year, Senator Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican, and Jake Sullivan, President Biden’s national security adviser, met to discuss China and industrial policy. During their conversation, Mr. Rubio raised his worries about Beijing’s influence over TikTok, the Chinese-owned viral video app.

articles.headline: Why Abortion Has Become a Centerpiece of Democratic TV Ads in 2022
articles.snippet: Since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Democrats have spent nearly eight times as much on abortion-related ads as Republicans have.
articles.abstract: Since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Democrats have spent nearly eight times as much on abortion-related ads as Republicans have.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Michigan, Democrats took aim at the Republican nominee for governor almost immediately after the primary with a television ad highlighting her opposition to abortion, without exceptions for rape or incest.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: After Roe v. Wade Reversal, Readers Flock to Publications Aimed at Women
articles.snippet: The surge of readers has buoyed a part of the digital media world that has gradually declined in recent years.
articles.abstract: The surge of readers has buoyed a part of the digital media world that has gradually declined in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the weeks since the Supreme Court reversed Roe v. Wade, overturning the right to abortion after almost 50 years, the consequences have quickly rippled through American life. States have banned abortion or restricted access. Individual stories about the real-life impacts have become national headlines. Concerns have flared about what the decision means for other civil rights.

articles.headline: I Was Skeptical of Baby Gear. Then I Became a Dad.
articles.snippet: Fears of pointless consumerism were no match for the joy and relief our gear provided.
articles.abstract: Fears of pointless consumerism were no match for the joy and relief our gear provided.
articles.lead_paragraph: When my wife was three months pregnant — before we had told most of our friends we were expecting, but after it was pretty clear the pregnancy would stick — she started making a list of baby gear.

articles.headline: 75 Years Later, the Fading Ghosts of India’s Bloody Partition
articles.snippet: With the passing decades, nationalist fervor and mutual suspicion have largely replaced memories of mass death and displacement during the chaotic cleaving of Pakistan from India.
articles.abstract: With the passing decades, nationalist fervor and mutual suspicion have largely replaced memories of mass death and displacement during the chaotic cleaving of Pakistan from India.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMRITSAR, India — For seven decades, Sudarshana Rani has ached to learn her younger brother’s fate. She was just a child when the communal bloodletting that surrounded Britain’s 1947 partition of India wiped out nearly her entire extended family. But in the paddy fields that became execution grounds, there was one body she did not find: that of her 5-year-old brother, Mulk Raj.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Zia ur-Rehman

articles.headline: The Rise of the Worker Productivity Score
articles.snippet: Across industries and incomes, more employees are being tracked, recorded and ranked. What is gained, companies say, is efficiency and accountability. What is lost?
articles.abstract: Across industries and incomes, more employees are being tracked, recorded and ranked. What is gained, companies say, is efficiency and accountability. What is lost?
articles.lead_paragraph: Across industries and incomes, more employees are being tracked, recorded and ranked. What is gained, companies say, is efficiency and accountability. What is lost?
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor, Arya Sundaram, Aliza Aufrichtig and Rumsey Taylor

articles.headline: Some Republicans Make a More Restrained Case for Defending Trump
articles.snippet: When some G.O.P. members of Congress attacked the nation’s top law enforcement agencies immediately after the F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago, it underscored deep fissures within the party.
articles.abstract: When some G.O.P. members of Congress attacked the nation’s top law enforcement agencies immediately after the F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago, it underscored deep fissures within the party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Republicans continued to defend former President Donald J. Trump after an unprecedented F.B.I. search of his residence in Florida, deep fissures were visible in the party’s support for law enforcement amid a federal investigation into Mr. Trump’s handling of top secret documents.

articles.headline: In Los Angeles, the Grass Isn’t Always Greener This Year
articles.snippet: Southern California residents are beginning to accept that lush lawns are unsustainable when reservoirs and rivers run low in a drought era.
articles.abstract: Southern California residents are beginning to accept that lush lawns are unsustainable when reservoirs and rivers run low in a drought era.
articles.lead_paragraph: AGOURA HILLS, Calif. — Erin Brockovich made her name decades ago as an environmental activist who exposed corporate wrongdoing that polluted drinking water.

articles.headline: If the Job Market Is So Good, Why Is Gig Work Thriving?
articles.snippet: Conventional employment opportunities abound, but online platforms still have appeal — for flexibility or additional income.
articles.abstract: Conventional employment opportunities abound, but online platforms still have appeal — for flexibility or additional income.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Six Weeks of ‘Hell’: Inside Russia’s Brutal Ukraine Detentions
articles.snippet: Thousands of Ukrainian civilians have suffered beatings and sometimes electrical shocks, while the U.N. says hundreds have disappeared into Russian jails.
articles.abstract: Thousands of Ukrainian civilians have suffered beatings and sometimes electrical shocks, while the U.N. says hundreds have disappeared into Russian jails.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — It was a particularly dangerous time for a military-age man in Russian-occupied northern Ukraine, where Russian troops were losing ground before a ferocious Ukrainian counterattack this past spring. That was when soldiers from the occupying forces seized a young auto mechanic while he was walking in his home village with his wife and a neighbor, blindfolded him, bound his hands and shoved him into a bus.

articles.headline: Adam Neumann’s New Company Gets a Big Check From Andreessen Horowitz
articles.snippet: After his spectacular rise and fall at WeWork, Mr. Neumann is getting back into the real estate industry, with backing from a major Silicon Valley player.
articles.abstract: After his spectacular rise and fall at WeWork, Mr. Neumann is getting back into the real estate industry, with backing from a major Silicon Valley player.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adam Neumann, the founder of WeWork whose spectacular rise and fall has been chronicled in books, documentaries and a scripted television series, has a new venture — and a surprising backer.
